newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil fiscal gap threatens stability-central bank.
newsitem.headline: Brazil fiscal gap threatens stability-central bank.

text.p: Brazil's fiscal deficit is still too wide to ensure sustained economic stability, even though progress has been made in narrowing the gap, a central bank director said Thursday.

Monetary Policy Director Francisco Lopes said the government's 1997 goal was to reduce the nominal consolidated public-sector deficit -- also known as the public-sector borrowing requirement (PSBR) -- to an equivalent of 5.0 percent of gross domestic product.

"This is still a lot. It is still too large to allow stability to be sustained," Lopes told the Chamber of Deputies Economics, Industry and Commerce Committee. "It's urgent, it's fundamental that we persist with our fiscal efforts."
As Lopes noted, Brazil managed to reduce its PSBR to 6.0 percent of GDP last year from 7.0 percent the previous year.

In the 12 months to the end of May, Brazil's public-sector PSBR -- which includes the accounts of the federal, state and municipal governments and state-owned companies -- stood at 5.53 percent of GDP versus 5.67 percent of GDP in the year to the end of April.
Lopes stuck by a government target for this year of generating a 1.5 percent fiscal surplus in the public sector in primary terms, which excludes interest payment on debt.
"That objective is perfectly achievable," he said, provided Congress passed key reforms in the civil service and pension system.
Both reforms have languished in Congress in part because they would remove public-sector privileges enjoyed by many lawmakers.
"I'm convinced that with the cooperation of Congress we will arrive at fiscal equilibrium over the next years," Lopes said. "There can be no permanent stability without fiscal equilibrium."
Lopes also told the committee he dreamed of a Brazil where "monetary austerity was institutionalized -- a permanent feature."
He said the central bank was making progress toward that end, with its Monetary Policy Committee (Copom) setting monthly interest rates on a purely technical basis.

In its three years of existence, the economic stabilization plan has slowed hyperinflation to a projected 6.0 percent this year through policies to encourage a strong exchange rate and high interest rates.
